__data__.text:
- The first kafana, or bistro, in Belgrade, serving only Turkish coffee, was opened in 1522 in Dorćol during the Ottoman period.
- Belgrade had kafanas and meyhanas in the 18th century, with almost 200 in the city, leading to a boom in alcoholic beverage production.
- Austrian governor Charles Alexander, Duke of Württemberg, encouraged nightlife by abolishing taxes on drink serving, resulting in 140 kafanas and pubs in the German section and over 200 in the Serbian sector.
- The Duke organized balls in his palace, with music in other parts of the city forbidden during these events. Common citizens were sometimes forcefully dragged to the balls and made to pay a high entry fee.
- After the return of the Ottomans in 1739, the "baroque blitz" of Belgrade's nightlife ended.
- The kafana "Crni orao" survived in the corner of Kralja Petra and Cara Dušana streets, serving coffee and nargile, and was the first brewery in Belgrade and the first venue to work 24/7.
- The White Bear Tavern in Zemun, built in the 17th century and serving as a caravanserai, is the oldest surviving building in urban Belgrade.
- The word kafana was derived from the Persian qahvah–khanah, meaning "coffee house", and the English version appeared for the first time in 1615.

- Zemun and Belgrade were separate entities until 1929, with the White Bear Tavern being the oldest house in Zemun.
- The term "kafana" was derived from the Persian qahvah–khanah, meaning "coffee house".
- Prince Alexander Karađorđević codified hospitality objects in 1847, dividing them into mehanas and khans.
- Traditional kafanas had clothless tables, loosen chairs, tinplate furnaces, and tallow candles or petroleum lamps.
- A culture of spending hours in kafanas developed among the lower classes.
- Development of westernized venues began, becoming gathering spots for officers, clerks, and landowners.
- Princess Ljubica Obrenović was a regular visitor of the fancy "Manojlova bašta", which was the first Belgrade's kafana to serve beer in 1835.
- Staying up late was against the law, and a subculture of bribery developed around it.
- Kafanas became centers of city's social life, with the entire political and cultural pulse of the city radiating from them.
- Prince Mihailo Obrenović codified kafanas in 1863, and ordered that women were not allowed to own the kafana nor to work in the village and road ones.
- Kafanas diversified into various types, including mehana, bistro, gostionica, han, saraj, lokal, krčma, bircuz, birtija, restoran, and hotel.
- Downtown Makedonska Street had 40 houses, of which 22 were kafanas, at the end of the 19th century.
- Kafanas were generally diversified, with some serving only coffee, others serving only beer or offering only bean soup.
- Kafanas were categorized in 1877, with kafanas of the first order being allowed to have one female waitress.
- "Esnafska kafana" was for craftsmen, "Makedonija" was for farmers and traders, and "Kod Albanije" was for leaseholders.
- Some kafanas

- Kafanas were social hubs in Serbia, categorized by the clientele they served.
 	+ Ex: "Esnafska kafana" for craftsmen, "Makedonija" for farmers and traders, etc.
- Kafanas became debate clubs for political parties.
- "Rajić" was the first kafana to prepare modern ćevapčići around 1860.
	+ Ćevapčići became popular, leading to 300 ćevabdžinicas in Belgrade at one point.
- "Kod Rajića junaka serbskog" hosted festivities after the Ottomans withdrew from Belgrade in 1867.
- The first hotel, "Kod jelena," was built in 1843 and became known as "Staro zdanje."
	+ It introduced European entertainment traditions and had the first ballroom in Belgrade.
- The first ball in Belgrade was held in 1838, with more frequent, strict dances after 1860.
- "Potato balls" were informal dance parties for the lower classes.
- A kafana allowed guests to stay the entire night after Christmas and Easter liturgies.
- The first electrified streetlamp was lit in 1893, marking the beginning of "proper night life."
- "Kod Albanije" was a well-known kafana, replaced by the Palace Albania in 1940.
- Kafanas had jovial or location-based names, like "Kod pocepanih gaća" and "Tri šešira."
- "Amerika" was known for Turkish delight, chickpeas, čočeks, belly dancers, and prostitution.
- Hotel and restaurant "Balkan" on Terazije was built in 1935 on the location of "Simina kafana" from 1860.
	+ It was a high-ranking meeting place for businesspeople and one of the few places women could work.

- Kafana "Amerika" was known for Turkish delight, chickpeas, čočeks, belly dancers, and prostitution.
- Hotel and restaurant "Balkan" on Terazije was built in 1935, replacing the former "Simina kafana" from 1860. It was a meeting place for businesspeople and one of the few places where women were allowed to work.
- "Zlatni krst" in Terazije, established in 1862, had 12 rooms and a stable for 30 horses.
- Unusual, exotic, and funny names for kafanas were common, often countering nearby or well-established venues. Examples include "Pivni izvor" (Beer Spring), "Bosfor" (Bosporus), "Engleska kraljica" (Queen of England), "Zemljotres" (Earthquake), "Crna mačka" (Black Cat), "Žurka" (Party), "Kod tri seljaka" (Chez Three Peasants), "Astronomska kugla" (Astronomy Ball), "Kod bombardovanja Beograda" (Chez Bombing of Belgrade), "Gusarski brod" (Pirate Ship), "Dva panja" (Two Logs), "Jeftinoća" (Cheapness), "Musa Kesedžija", "Radosan Srbin" (Joyful Serb), "Srpski vlakovođa" (Serbian Train Driver), "Crni Arapin" (Black Arab), "U modrim šumama" (In Blue Forests), "Kod dve misterije" (Chez Two Mysteries), "Kod Oroza" (Chez Trigger), "Vrući gavran" (Hot Raven), "Izgubljeno jagnje" (Lost Lamb), or "Kod žirafu vanevropsku zverku" (Chez giraffe, out-of-Europe beast).
- "Srpska kruna", built in 1869, was famous for its balls and originated in 1853 at the corner of

- The passage discusses the history of kafanas (traditional taverns) and nightlife in Belgrade, Serbia.
- Notable kafanas mentioned include:
  - "Bibija" (also known as "people's university"), which was frequented by notable guests such as Vojislav Ilić, Branislav Nušić, Antun Gustav Matoš, Stevan Sremac, Radoje Domanović, Janko Veselinović, Toša Jovanović, Đura Jakšić, and Milovan Glišić. It was demolished in 1901 and its clientele moved to "Velika Srbija" and Skadarlija.
  - "Tri šešira", founded in 1864, is the oldest still operational kafana in Skadarlija and second overall in Belgrade.
  - "Grčka Kraljica", opened in 1835 and closed in 2007.
  - "Despotov Han" inn, predecessor of "Grčka Kraljica", was the first recorded brothel in Belgrade.
- The Bibija stream, flowing down the Skadarlija, was an administrative border between the quarters of Palilula and Dorćol.
- Belgrade was divided into quarters and had one hospitality or catering venue per 50 inhabitants at the turn of the 19th and the 20th century.
- After World War I, new venues were completely westernized and the social divide remained.
- Among the most luxurious and exclusive nightlife locales during the Interbellum was "Srpski Kralj", which was completely destroyed during the German bombing of Belgrade on 6 April 1941.
- On 30 December 1927, the Ministry of Finance of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes banned night life after 23:00.

- The passage describes various kafanas (traditional taverns) and other establishments in Belgrade, Serbia, before and after World War I.
- The "ornament" of the city, a lavish hotel with beautiful interior and exterior, was destroyed in 1941 during the German bombing of Belgrade and never rebuilt.
- In 1927, the Ministry of Finance of the Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes banned nightlife after 23:00, imposing a "tax for nighttime sitting" of two dinars.
- "Park" restaurant, later renamed to "Central Park", was opened on the lot of the destroyed hotel. It burned down in December 2012.
- "Babuna" kafana was located in Senjak, across from the modern Belgrade Fair, and hosted the monument Pobednik before it was erected on the Belgrade Fortress.
- "Bajlonijeva kafana", owned by Czech émigré Ignjat Bajloni, was known for its beer and fresh hops aroma. It hosted concerts of the "Abrašević Choir" after 1907.
- "Boem" kafana in Cetinjska Street was popular during the Interbellum and known for its specific music: schlagers, serenades, and arias from operas and operettas.
- "Bulevar" kafana in Terazije was popular for its large hall where parties were organized, including regular concerts of the Serbian-Jewish Singing Society and shows of German theatrical groups.
- "Bums Keler" kafana in Skadarlija, owned by Pera Bums, was praised for its nicely arranged garden, good snacks, and excellent wine.
- "Cvetkova mehana" was opened in 1902 by Cvetko Jovanović on the Smederevo road and became so famous that the entire neighborhood and the modern Svetogorska Street were named after it.
- "Čukareva kafana" existed in the later 19th century and was named after its owner, Stojko Čukar. It gave name to the modern neighborhood and municipality Čukar

- "Dva bela goluba" (Two White Doves): Originally a meyhane founded by Jovan Kujundžić, a tailor. The kafana became famous and the entire neighborhood and modern Svetogorska Street were named after it in 1872. The building now houses the Radio Belgrade.
- "Dva duda" (Two Pigeons): Located close to Tašmajdan, visited by Belgrade's coachmen and porters.
- "Era Gurman": At modern 6 Nikola Pašić Square, where the building of Belgrade City administration is today. Known for having the best grilled and roasted meat in town.
- "Građanska kasina" (Civil Casino): At the corner of Kralja Petra and Knez Mihailova streets. The clientele included the most respected and educated Belgrade merchants, high-ranking officers and clerks. The Red Cross of Serbia was founded here in 1876, as well as the Serbian Journalists Association in 1881 and Belgrade Stock Exchange in 1894.
- "Kazbek": The most famous "Russian" kafana, established after the massive Russian White emigration. Opened in November 1931, it was a venue on "European level" and labeled a center of Belgrade's nightlife.
- "London": Gave name to the modern surrounding neighborhood, at the crossroads of the Kneza Miloša and Kralja Milana streets. Built between 1865 and 1873, with hotel rooms above it. Belgrade's first korzo (promenade) formed next to it.
- "Malo Pristanište" (Small Pier): In Savamala, it was the starting point for the boat transport to the other side of the river, and the Nica Beach before World War II.
- "Manakova kuća" (Manak's House): In the Bosanska (now 7 Gavrila Principa) Street in Savamala. Built for the local Turkish agha and his harem, later turned into a meyhane and bakery.
- "Mostar": Named after the

- "Mostar" kafana:
	+ Closed, but house survived
	+ Protected by state in 1963, declared cultural monument in 1979
	+ Named after small bridge (most) across Mokroluški potok
	+ Gave name to modern Mostar neighborhood and large interchange

- "Novi Beograd" kafana:
	+ Opened in 1924 by Petar Kokotović
	+ In informal suburban settlement of Tošin Bunar
	+ Name prophetic as modern municipality New Belgrade named that way in 1948

- "Nica" kafana:
	+ Located on sandy beach across Sava in modern Ušće in New Belgrade
	+ One of favorite vacation spots during Interbellum
	+ Only one in a string of kafanas along unurbanized bank to survive construction of King Alexander Bridge
	+ Beach became largest city beach and named "Nica"
	+ Beach closed in 1938 during construction of embankment

- "Pariz" kafana:
	+ Originally "Ćosina kafana"
	+ Founded in 1830s by Anđelko Alekić Ćosa
	+ New building constructed in 1868, finished in 1870
	+ Situated between "Kasina" and "Takovo"
	+ Location of first Serbian comedy theatre "Orfeum"
	+ First Serbian feature film partially filmed and shown in venue
	+ Demolished during reconstruction of Terazije in 1948

- "Pozorišna kafana":
	+ Opened in 1902 as "Pozorišna kasina"
	+ Favorite choice of actors, bohemians, and other artists
	+ Actors and journalists' associations founded in it

- "Rudničanin" kafana:
	+ At corner of Beogradska and Kralja Milana streets
	+ Major transloading and packaging spot in Belgrade before Belgrade Main railway station opened in 1884
	+ Goods and food arriving from interior stored and rep

- "Takovo" kafana in Terazije, frequented by actors and Liberals, with composer Stevan Mokranjac as a regular
- "Topola" kafana in Nikola Pašić Square, popular among lawyers for writing claims and complaints
- "Zeleni Venac" kafana, established around 1840 by Mrs. Hermann, a young hatmaker's widow, with a tin-made green wreath on the façade
- "Zlatna lađa" kafana, built by wealthy merchant Miša Anastasijević, a meeting place for merchants and prominent people
- "Zlatni krst" kafana, location of the first cinema show in Belgrade in 1896, later the favorite place of politicians
- "Zlatni šaran" kafana in Jalija, known for its fish meals and famous for its fish broth
- "Župa" kafana in Jajinci, location of the first modern traffic sign, first concrete paved street, and a pitstop in the first races organized in Belgrade
- In Zemun, from 1730 to 1871, Kontumac or the quarantine hospital existed, with numerous kafanas opened around it such as "Kod zlatnog krsta", "Kod zlatnog točka", "Kod cara", "Kod zlatnog slona", "Kod zlatnog sunca"
- After World War II, nightlife dwindled, but new kafanas were established near sports clubs and stadiums, such as "Mladi Proleter", "Sinđelić", "Obilić" or "Stadion"

- After World War II, nightlife in Belgrade dwindled due to heavy city damage, population loss, and lack of public transportation.
- Kafanas (traditional taverns) re-emerged in the 1950s-1960s near sports clubs and stadiums, such as "Mladi Proleter," "Sinđelić," "Obilić," and "Stadion."
- Riverbank kafanas, particularly in Zemun, were also popular nightlife spots.
- The rise of radio and television, including popular comedy shows and the introduction of Television Belgrade in 1958, impacted the importance of kafanas.
- In the mid-1950s, "Lotos Bar" in Zmaj Jovina Street became a sensation with its artistic program, including magicians, jugglers, and female dancers, evolving into a not-so-hidden prostitution locale.
- Similar venues followed, like "Kristal Bar," "Mažestik" and "Metropol" hotels, and numerous striptease clubs in the 1990s.
- Street prostitution developed in the late 1960s, with sex workers operating near the Pančevo Bridge and the Economy Faculty's Park.
- The "Blue Bridge" became synonymous with prostitution.
- Old-style brothels, porn-shops, and business escort agencies also emerged in the 1990s.
- New Belgrade, built from 1948, initially had no nightlife due to the lack of kafanas.
- "Split," the first kafana on a boat, opened in 1970 and had historical significance as the precursor of splavovi (floating river clubs).
- Kafanas evolved into westernized restaurants, but many traditional ones survived and remained part of Belgrade's tourist offer.

- The restaurant is located in a ship built in 1892 for the Serbian Royal Navy Society in Regensburg, Germany.
- Originally named Emperor Nicholas II, it was used for diplomatic missions and was part of the Kladovo transport in World War II.
- After the war, it was renamed Split and docked in Belgrade, where it was adapted into a restaurant.
- The ship's steerage was used for prostitution, leading to frequent police raids.
- In 1992, the ship was moved to a dry dock in Kladovo and declared a cultural monument in 2006.
- Skadarlija, the street where the restaurant is located, began to develop in 1830 and acquired its bohemian character in the late 19th century.
- In the early 20th century, there were 15 kafanas, or traditional Serbian taverns, in Skadarlija, including "Tri šešira", "Dva jelena", and "Zlatni bokal", which still exist today.
- The renovation and restoration of Skadarlija began in 1968, and it has since become a popular tourist destination and center of bohemian culture in Belgrade.
- The official opening of the summer season in Skadarlija is marked by the raising of a "bohemian flag" and follows a specific code of conduct for restaurants and their employees.
- The symbol of Skadarlija is a Fedora hat, and it is known for its traditional Serbian music, including the starogradska musical style.
- Notable performers in Skadarlija include Toma Zdravković, Silvana Armenulić, Olga Jančevecka, and Sofka Nikolić, who was a popular folk music star in the 1920s and 1930s and befriended Josephine Baker.

* Skadarlija and Čubura are two neighborhoods in Belgrade, Serbia, known for their bohemian culture and kafanas (traditional taverns).
* Skadarlija is considered a fancy and fashionable place, while Čubura was historically a gathering place of common people.
* Skadarlija is known for its starogradska musical style and performers such as Toma Zdravković, Silvana Armenulić, Olga Jančevecka, and Sofka Nikolić. Nikolić, known as the "Queen of Skadarlija," was a popular singer in the 1920s and 1930s who published dozens of records and was friends with celebrities like Josephine Baker.
* Čubura was once home to over 30 kafanas along Makenzijeva Street and was described as "one vast kafana, open all hours."
* After 1945, certain kafanas in Čubura became gathering places for different groups of people, such as "Vltava" for lawyers, "Mala Vltava" for former political prisoners, and "Trandafilović" for more affluent citizens.
* "Orač" was originally opened in Savinac in 1949 and was famous for its grill menu. It was relocated to Čubura in 1996 and closed in 2015.
* "Mlava" was an iconic kafana known for its traditional interior and bohemian clientele. It was closed in 2013.
* "Trandafilović" was founded in 1929 and was known for its old plane tree in the yard. It was demolished in 1961 but reopened in 1967 in a new building on the same location. It was turned into a household chemicals shop in the 21st century.
* A bistro named "Trandafilović" now stands where the old kafana used to be, under the surviving plane tree.
* A monument dedicated to the nameless "Crna Trava builder" was erected in Čubura Park in 2019.
* By the 2020s,

- "?" kafana, opened in 1823, is the oldest still operational kafana in Belgrade with a menu that has remained almost the same for 200 years. The name "?" came about after a dispute with the Serbian Orthodox Church, and the question mark remains above the entrance to this day. The first pool table in Belgrade was installed here in 1834.
- "Bled" kafana, known for its fish cuisine, was established in the early 20th century near the Jevremovac botanical garden. It was closed in 2008 and reopened in 2018.
- "Golf" kafana, built in the late 1920s and designed by Dragiša Brašovan, was originally used as a children's vacation and recuperation facility. It was later adapted into a training facility for the Masters (Catering) School and is now a hospitality venue.
- "Hotel Moskva", built in 1908, was a popular social spot where Serbian governments were formed or brought down. The hotel's restaurant was famous for its salon orchestra and tangos.
- "Kalenić" kafana, opened in 1938, was owned by Adolf Sabo who perished in the Holocaust. The kafana was nationalized and in 2018, the ownership was transferred to the Belgrade's Jewish municipality.
- "Klub Književnika" at 7 Francuska Street, established in 1946, is highly esteemed among the intellectual elite and has been visited by numerous renowned writers.
- "Kolarac" kafana, founded in 1857, was an elite kafana that held the most important and largest balls in Belgrade. The kafana moved to Knez Mihailova Street after its original building was demolished.
- "Lipov lad" kafana, opened in 1928, became trendy in the late 1950s as a meeting place of artists, actors, poets and local bohemians, and later became a popular family venue.
- "Čuburska lipa" kafana, named after the linden tree

- Kafana (traditional tavern) in Belgrade, Serbia, known as "Kolarac," was a popular venue for large balls and gatherings of military officers, high-ranking officials, politicians, artists, and members of various societies.
- Austrian and later Austro-Hungarian consulate was located in the same building from 1861 to 1878.
- The first Serbian intercity phone line was opened from "Kolarac" to the city of Niš in 1896.
- The building was later demolished, and the kafana moved to Knez Mihailova Street.
- "Lipov lad" (Linden Tree) kafana was opened in 1928 and became a trendy meeting place for artists, actors, poets, and local bohemians in the late 1950s.
- In 1972, the entire neighborhood was reconstructed, including the old kafana, but the linden trees which gave name to the kafana were preserved.
- "Madera" kafana was built in 1937 and named after a guest who brought high-quality Madeira wine.
- It became a distinguished venue known for its Bohemian clientele of athletes, journalists, and actors, called Maderaši.
- The venue was refurbished in 2003.
- "Mornar" (Sailor) kafana is one of the best-known journalists' kafanas in Belgrade.
- It was the first venue with an electronic cash register in Belgrade in the 1980s.
- "Orašac" kafana is highly esteemed among Belgrade bohemians and has the "best grill under the sun."
- City plans in 2001 included demolition of the venue, but it survived.
- In 2021, the plans were revived.
- "Polet" (Flight) fish restaurant is famous for its fried girice and was founded in 1952.
- It was closed in 2014 and reopened in 2017.
- "Poslednja Šansa" (Last Chance) kafana is situated in

- "Ruski car":
	+ Opened in 1890 in Varoš Kapija area, popular among professors and students of Belgrade University
	+ Named after assassinated tzar Alexander II of Russia
	+ Finished current building in 1926, became meeting place for noble citizens and intellectual elite
	+ Confiscated by communist authorities after WWII, nationalized in 1960
	+ First Belgrade "express restaurant" opened, original luxurious interior demolished, name changed to "Zagreb"
	+ Renovated and renamed to "Vapiano" in the 1990s, reopened under original name in Dec 2019

- "Srpska kafana":
	+ Opened in 1923 by merchant Luka Đurić, originally named "Kod Ere"
	+ Became special place for Atelje 212 actors and theatrical people after relocation in 1964
	+ Nationalized after WWII, returned to Đurić's descendants in restitution process
	+ Closed for renovation in 2017, reopened in 2018 with reporters saying "Svetogorska breathes again"

- "Stara Hercegovina" (formerly "Skoplje"):
	+ Named "gastronomical Mecca" in Stari Grad
	+ Opened in 1923, renamed to "Stara Hercegovina" in 1991

- "Sunce":
	+ Opened in 1966 next to Belgrade Youth Center
	+ Became exclusive restaurant and gathering place for Belgrade's crème de la crème
	+ Gained reputation as "advocates" venue

- "Šaran":
	+ Established in 1896 in Zemun, originally a gathering place for local fishermen and ferry passengers
	+ Now one of the "first associations on Zemun"

- "Ušće":
	+ Built in 1960, featured in movies, music videos, and broadcasts
	+ Refurbished and reopened as "Nacionalna

- "Zlatno burence" kafana, also known as "Kafana on the Stone Barrel", is a historic venue in Belgrade, Serbia, known as a gathering point for the Komite and members of the Serbian Chetnik Organization.
- Originally opened in 1866, the kafana was a recruitment center for volunteers in the Serbian-Turkish and Balkan Wars.
- The original building was demolished in the early 1930s and replaced with a modern highrise, but the kafana was rebuilt near its original location.
- A popular but likely false anecdote is that Winston Churchill was beaten up in the kafana while working as a journalist.
- The Bermuda Triangle is a name given to three rival kafanas in Makedonska Street, known for their bohemian clientele and red-white checkered tablecloths.
- The name "Bermuda Triangle" emerged in the 1960s and became popular in the 1980s, referring to the disappearance of writers and journalists for several days at a time.
- The three kafanas in the Bermuda Triangle are "Grmeč", "Pod lipom", and "Šumatovac".
- "Grmeč" was originally a beer hall opened in the mid-1930s, and was renamed after the Grmeč mountain after World War II. It was closed in 2011 but reopened in 2018.
- "Pod lipom" was founded during the Interbellum as a restaurant-bowling alley and gathering place for Slovenes in Belgrade. It was demolished in the late 1960s and rebuilt in 1971, but has since been turned into a store.
- "Šumatovac" was a kafana known for its patrons of journalists, writers, opera singers, actors, athletes, and professional gamblers. It was closed from 2013 to 2015, and has since reopened as a restaurant.
- Other well-known venues in Belgrade that have closed since the economic collapse in the late 1980s include "Atina", which was located in Terazije

- 1971: New building constructed, new restaurant opened (later turned into Pizza Hut and then a store)
- Šumatovac: Building at No. 33, housed various professionals from 1900s to 2013-2015, reopened as more of a restaurant than a kafana
- Atina: Kafana in Terazije, opened in the 1970s-1980s as the first pizzeria in Belgrade, closed in 2003
- Buffet of Hotel Bristol: Located near Belgrade Main railway and bus stations, popular in the 2010s with a mix of "cultural and non-cultural" clientele, interiors unchanged from the 1960s-1970s, closed in 2018
- Grgeč: 19th century kafana demolished during WWII, new restaurant opened in the late 1950s, named after the original, became a favorite spot for journalists and reporters, closed in 2007 and replaced by McDonald's
- Kasina: Established in 1858, named after the Italian word casino, "headquarter" of Progressive party members, temporarily hosted National Assembly and National Theatre, present building finished in 1922, restaurant famous for fast food-type sold Wiener schnitzels no longer exists
- Lion: Opened during Interbellum, named after the French city of Lyon, clientele included state clerks, military officers, teachers and writers, became a "typical socialist kafana" after WWII, turned into the restaurant and then brewery, closed by the end of the 1990s and turned into a grocery store
- Mihajlovac: Best known kafana in Banovo Brdo, demolished in 2017
- Promaja: Mentioned in 1906, described as a symbol of the city spirit, located in Savamala, forcefully demolished in 2019
- Tri lista duvana: Founded in 1882, first phone line in Serbia conducted here in 1883, building demolished in 1989 to

- "Tri lista duvana": Founded in 1882, it was one of the most famous Belgrade kafanas. The first phone line in Serbia was conducted here in 1883. The building was demolished in 1989 to make way for the Hilton Hotel which was never built.
- "Vidin kapija": Opened in 1861, it was originally named "Kod sedam hrabrih Švaba" after German contractors built the neighboring First Town Hospital. It was a popular spot for famous cultural and scientific figures. It was reopened as "Vidin kapija" in the late 1950s, then closed and reopened as the ultra-modern club "Medžik" designed by Karim Rashid. It has since been closed and reopened as several other venues.
- "Zora": Located in the Balkan Cinema building, it succeeded the pre-World War II kafana "Ruska lira". It was a popular spot for pilots of the 6th Fighter Aviation Regiment. It was closed in 2002 and turned into a casino. A new kafana was opened in the same location in 2012, but was reported as "face-lifted for new customers" and is now referred to as "Žagubica" by citizens.
- "Žagubica": A popular old-style kafana located at the busy corner of Ruzveltova and 27. Marta (today Kraljice Marije) streets. It was later turned into a modern café and renamed "Tramvaj", but citizens continue to refer to the building and its location as "Žagubica".
- Other notable kafanas: "Marš na Drinu" (Dorćol), "Beli grad" (Zeleni Venac), "Morava", "Plitvice" (Šumice), "Složna braća" (demolished), "Vardar" (Cvetni trg), "Tabor" (Vračar), "Mala astronomija", "Velika astronomija" (both in Savinac), "Arilje", "Zona Zamfirova" (Cvet

- Kafanas were the first democratic space in society, open to all without requirements of literacy, membership, or party discipline.
- They served as gathering places and recruitment centers for various wars and rebellions, such as "Crni Konj" and "Kragujevac."
- Kafanas were important for the economy, serving as the first public places for drafting contracts and merchant treaties, and hosting institutions like banks, exchange offices, labor markets, stock exchanges, insurance offices, private medical offices, and photographic studios.
- The first Serbian Bank was established in "Staro Zdanje" in 1826, but went bankrupt in 1875.
- The first telephone line in Belgrade was installed in "Tri lista duvana" in 1881.
- The first light bulb in Belgrade was lit in "Hamburg" in 1882.
- The first public motion picture show in Serbia was held in "Zlatni krst" on Terazije on 6 June 1896, with the Lumière brothers personally showing the film.
- The first intercity phone line was established from "Kolarac" to the city of Niš in 1896.
- Travelling cinemas began to show movies in "Kasina" in the 1900s, and the first permanent cinema was opened there in 1910.
- "Kolarac" was a regular meeting place of young officers headed by Dragutin Dimitrijević Apis, who plotted the 1903 May Coup there.
- Every guild had "its own" kafana.
- Kafanas hosted numerous firsts in Belgrade, including the first game of billiard in 1834, the first assembly after the return of Prince Miloš Obrenović to the throne in 1859, the official celebration of the complete handing over of the city by the Ottomans to the Serbs in 1867, the founding of the Red Cross of Serbia in 1876, and the founding of the Serbian Journalists Association in 1881.
- The Belgrade Stock Exchange was opened in "Kasina" in 1894, which also hosted

- 1896: First intercity phone line established between "Kolarac" in Belgrade and Niš, with a concert of the vocal ensemble "Stanković" in Belgrade and a singers' society "Branko" in Niš.
- 1900s:
  - Lumière brothers' camera in Belgrade, kept at Yugoslav Film Archive.
  - Travelling cinemas began to show movies in "Kasina", first permanent cinema opened in 1910.
  - "Kolarac" was a regular meeting place for young officers, including Dragutin Dimitrijević Apis, who plotted the 1903 May Coup.
  - First book fair in the city held at "Kolarac".
  - First individual public clock placed in front of "Kod Albanije".
- 1905: Elementary school "Karađorđe" established in "Gavrilović", operating as a school by day and kafana in the afternoon and evening.
- 1900s-1910s:
  - Members of the revolutionary movement Young Bosnia, including Gavrilo Princip, gathered in "Zlatna Moruna" and planned actions, including the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914.
  - Neighborhoods and buildings named after kafanas: Zeleni Venac, London, Lipov Lad, Mostar, Lion, Čukarica, Cvetko, Golf, Gospodarska Mehana, Dva Bela Goluba, Palace Albanija, Ruski Car, Mihajlovac, Žagubica, Park "Tri ključa".
- 2023: 18 former or still operational catering and tourist facilities declared cultural monuments.
- Post World War II (1945-1963):
  - Prolonged dance evenings "till dawn" (igranke), with new types of music like kozaračko kolo, Russian romances, jazz, swing, and boogie-woogie.
  - Western music popular after the film Sun Valley Serenade with Glenn Miller's music reached Yugoslav cinemas.

- Public reaction to rock and roll in Yugoslavia was generally cold and indifferent, with older generations not perceiving it as a problem.
- Yugoslavia was more open to foreign influences compared to other Communist states, allowing for the creation of numerous rock bands, known as vokalno-instrumentalni sastavi (VIS).
- Nikola Karaklajić, a chess master and editor at Radio Belgrade, was a pioneer promoter of rock and roll through his TV show "Concert for crazy young people" which premiered in 1967.
- Džuboks, a printed media, was one of the most influential in promoting rock and roll, debuting on 3 May 1966.
- Entry to clubs in the 1960s was free or symbolic, with security guards checking for underage and intoxicated individuals.
- Euridika, a club located in a private house at 33 Molerova Street in Vračar, was an offshoot of the Youth Theater DADOV and became an important cultural hotspot in the late 1960s.
- Performers at Euridika included Elipse, Safiri, Zlatni Dečaci, Dobri Drugovi, Crni Biseri, Crni Panteri, Boba Stefanović, etc.
- The Youth Center at 22 Makedonska Street was opened in 1964, with a dancing hall introduced in 1966. Live performances included popular rock bands like Siluete, Crni Biseri, Džentlmeni, Zlatni Dečaci.
- The disco was adapted into the discothèque "202" in 1969 in collaboration with Radio Belgrade 202 station.
- "Kod Laze Šećera" was the first proper disco in Belgrade, opened on 24 April 1967 in Jevrem Grujić's House in Stari Grad. It was one of the first discos in Europe, opening before the famous Studio 54 in New York City.

- Event: Opening of the first disco in Yugoslavia, named "Lola" or "KST"
- Date: 29 February 1968
- Location: 17 Ive Lole Ribara Street, Jevrem Grujić's House, basement, Belgrade, Serbia
- Founder: Lazar Šećerović
- Co-founders/supporters: Mira Trailović, Jovan Ćirilov, Ivan Tabaković, Dušan Matić, KK Crvena Zvezda
- Description: Small venue, green Italian wallpapers, black floor linoleum, capacity for 150 people, working hours from 18:30 to 1:00
- Music: Soul, including Aretha Franklin, Otis Redding, The Temptations, Dusty Springfield
- Firsts: Girls without male companions, people dancing alone, after parties, pop art exhibition
- International guests: Pierre Cardin, Paco Rabanne, Catherine Deneuve, Judi Dench, Nina Ricci, Omar Sharif, Marisa Berenson, Alain Delon, Claudia Cardinale
- Rock bands practiced in the club during the day
- First pop art exhibition in Yugoslavia, including Roy Lichtenstein's graphics and Andy Warhol's lithographs
- Opposition: Municipal authorities, neighbors, citizens who tried to prevent the club from opening
- Accusations: Lair for young alcoholics, junkies, debauchers and rich kids, loud noise, unbridled youngsters causing commotion, playing "enemy music", destroying the morality of the Socialist youth, CIA headquarters in Yugoslavia
- Closure: 1968, due to authorities' and neighbors' pressure
- Previous existence: KST, unofficially established in 1952, official in 1954, located in a laboratory at 73 Bulevar Revolucije, today Bulevar Kralja Aleksandra
- Music variety: funk, soul, disco, rock and roll, twist, waltz.

- KST (Klub studenata tehnike) unofficially established in 1952, officially recognized in 1954, located at 73 Bulevar Revolucije (today Bulevar Kralja Aleksandra)
- Originally a study space and dance party location for students of architecture, electrical engineering, and civil engineering
- Disco opened in 1968, playing funk, soul, disco, rock and roll, twist, waltz, and promoting young musicians
- First "unplugged" concert in the Balkans performed by Bijelo Dugme
- Venue known for relaxed, home-style dress code and cult status among city youth
- SKC (Studentski Kulturni Centar) opened in 1968 at 48 Kralja Milana Street as a "safe haven" for avant-garde artists and alternative rock music
- Regular performances by Idoli, Električni Orgazam, and Šarlo Akrobata, with two main spaces, a café, bookstore, and art exhibitions
- At the start of the 1970s, nightlife for the young was undeveloped with predominant kafanas and few dance halls or venues with jukeboxes
- Popular disco clubs included "Youth Center", "Go-Go Dancing" in Tašmajdan, and "Disco Club 202" in the old synagogue in Zemun
- Belgrade began to resemble other world metropolises in the late 1970s with the development of numerous internationally important events in theatre, film, and music.

- Kafanas adapted for youth didn't exist, only a few dance halls and dilettante dance parties
- Most popular disco clubs: Youth Center, Go-Go Dancing in Tašmajdan, Disco Club 202 in Zemun synagogue
- Entry fees to clubs were expensive, drinks also became expensive due to lack of inspections
- Clubs open 7 days a week, usually 1 non-working day, working hours mostly didn't extend after 2 a.m.
- Clubs secured patronage of state-owned institutions and registered as "restaurants with music"
- 1978, modern caffe bar "Zlatni papagaj" opened, planned as standing bar for quick drinks
- 1970, "Dijalog" restaurant opened on a proper boat, Slobodan Milošević interviewed there in late 1980s
- Disco club "Crveno i crno" opened in 1970, achieved cult status, closed in 1971
- 1971, "Cepelin" opened, considered first proper disco club in Belgrade, open to everyone
- "Cepelin" located at 28 Ilije Garašanina Street, Tašmajdan, had 3 dance floors, state of the art sound system
- "Cepelin" interior patterned after London club "La Valbonne", had black artificial leather floors, brass ornaments, luxurious booths
- "Cepelin" had plush covered armchairs, 20 different types of mirrors, 1,000 colored lightbulbs, strobe lights, blacklights
- "Cepelin" had projector emitting psychedelic music videos on walls, rooms were stuffy, parts of walls and furniture in red with colorful flower prints
- Popular figures in "Cepelin" included DJ Mister Čupko, head-to-toe tattooed main bouncer nicknamed Oumpah-pah, Đorđe Božović Giška and his entourage
- "Cepelin" sponsored by Tašmajdan Sports and Recreation Center, located next to Fifth Gymnasium.

- "Cepelin" club:
  - Located near Fifth Gymnasium, sponsored by Tašmajdan Sports and Recreation Center.
  - Opened by Saša Nikolić with working hours of 16:00-21:00 (minors) and 21:00-24:00 (adults).
  - DJs included Saša Radosavljević and Raša Petrović in a glass booth above the dance podium.
  - Expanded in mid-1970s, featured live performances from popular Yugoslav rock bands.
  - Closed in 1980, reopened as "Taš", attracting some of the "Cepelin" visitors.

- "Akvarijus" club:
  - Located at 7 Deligradska Street near Slavija Square, in the basement of painter Radovan Trnavac Mića house.
  - Opened by Dodig in 1972, sponsored by Radnički Sports Association.
  - Named after the large aquarium in the central room.
  - Open every day, all night, with fashionable visitors from the city elite (sports, film, fashion).
  - Closed in 1983.

- Other clubs:
  - "Crveni Pevac": rock place in Topličin Venac, visited by bikers.
  - "F(ilozof)": founded in 1975 by the youth organization of the University of Belgrade Faculty of Philosophy.
  - "Mažestik": opened by Nikolić in the hotel of the same name in Obilićev Venac.
  - "Monokl": opened in bohemian Skadarlija, featured Silvana Armenulić at the opening.
  - "Resnik": opened in the suburb of Resnik, in the former adult movie theater.

- Notable figures:
  - DJ Mister Čupko, main bouncer Oumpah-pah, Đorđe Božović Giška, Saša Nikolić, DJ Saša Radosavljević, Raša Petrović, Krist

- Kristijan Golubović and Dragan Nikolić Gagi raided the venue "Monokl" in Skadarlija in 1990, forcing everyone to lay on the ground and firing shots into the ceiling.
- "Monokl" was a bohemian venue, opened across from "Tri šešira" and had Silvana Armenulić perform at its opening. DJ Maksa Ćatović worked there.
- "Resnik" was a club opened in the Resnik suburb in a former adult movie theater. It wasn't well-attended due to its distance from downtown.
- In 1981, "Akademija" club opened at 53 Knez Mihailova Street in the Gallery of the Painting Academy's basement. It was a rock and roll venue and a meeting place for rockers, artists, and politicians' children.
- The original line-up of Ekaterina Velika gathered here, as well as musicians like Električni Orgazam, Partibrejkers, Psihomodo Pop, and Toni Montano.
- "Akademija" was considered a "hole which shocks and provokes" and was a gathering point for the Belgrade youth of the decade.
- "Zvezda" was a rival club to "Akademija" and was located at 51 Knez Mihailova Street. It was the symbol of fanciness, with expensive interiors, imported perfumes, and modern wardrobe required for entry.
- "Duga" was a club located at 5 Sredačka Street and was opened in 1981. It was an exclusive venue that gathered the rich and famous, with over 200,000 Deutsche Marks spent on its adaptation.
- Legendary actor Zoran Radmilović would regularly visit "Duga" in slippers for coffee.
- One of the first barges was opened in the late 1970s.

- "Duga" club:
  * Opened in 1981 in Zvezdara
  * Most exclusive venue in its time, rearranged basement of a private house for over 200,000 Deutsche Marks
  * Attracted rich and famous, known as the "club for the famous"
  * Legendary actor Zoran Radmilović would regularly visit in slippers for coffee

- JAT river barge:
  * Opened in the late 1970s for JAT Airways employees, later became a gathering place for regular clientele
  * Sold to a private owner in the 2000s, sank in January 2019 due to heavy snowfall

- Other clubs in the 1980s:
  * "Bezistan": basement venue in Terazije, organized Italo disco dance competitions, closed in 1989
  * "Bona fides": founded by University of Belgrade Faculty of Law students
  * "Crveni podijum": largest open-air disco in the Balkans with up to 10,000 visitors
  * "Cvetni Breg": in Resnik
  * "London": in the London neighborhood
  * "Panorama": in Košutnjak
  * "Šestica": on the 6th floor of Beograđanka building, operated from 20:00 to 24:00, notorious for stuffiness
  * "Taš": replaced "Cepelin", introduced whiskey as a symbol of prestige, Knez worked as a DJ before becoming a singer

- Splavovi origins in the 1980s:
  * "Argument": first restaurant on splav, opened in 1983 on Ada Ciganlija, later moved to Ušće
  * "Hua Hua": opened in 1983, most popular splav in the 1980s, sold in 2013
  * "Savski Galeb": opened in 1987, first splav on the Sava Quay, adapted old freight barge

- 1990s in Serbia:

- 1983 marks the birth of splavovi (barge-clubs) in Belgrade, with "Hua Hua" being the most popular in the 1980s.
- Splavovi gained popularity in the 1990s as disco clubs became dangerous due to criminal activity and turbo-folk music becoming mainstream.
- Popular splavovi in the 1990s included "Lukas", "Mozzart", and "Triton".
- By 2021, there were over 200 cafes, restaurants, kafanas, and discos on the barges.
- The first urban splavovi appeared in Staro Sajmište in the second half of the 1990s, becoming mainstream and causing public conflict due to the area's war history.
- The splav "Pingvin", later renamed "Duga", was the first purposely built barge-discotheque and a blueprint for future venues.
- "Nana" was originally an elegant nightclub with a sophisticated atmosphere, but later became a gathering point for criminal clans.
- The 1990s saw a development of electronic music venues and a strict division between folk and underground techno clubs.

- "Barge with a DJ" at the left bank of the Savar, Ušće:
  * Opened in 1985, gained fame in the 1990s
  * Originally visited by "roamers" from all over the city
  * Later became gathering place for criminal clans from Zemun and New Belgrade
  * First club where a murder occurred (Andrija Lakonić Laki in 1990)
  * Connection between criminals and secret police revealed
  * Closed and reopened, but gained notoriety and avoided by many
  * Aleksandar Savković, member of FK Rad's supporter group, killed in 2017

- "Nana" at 3-a Koste Glavinića Street in Senjak:
  * Elegant nightclub with urban and sophisticated atmosphere
  * Known for not playing folk music
  * Favorite place of foreign diplomats in the late 1980s
  * Dress code (obligatory suit since 1987)
  * Discovered by criminals who began to gather and organize in local clans
  * First club where a murder occurred (Andrija Lakonić Laki in 1990)
  * Notorious connections between criminals and the secret police
  * Trial dragged on with many criminals and policemen appearing
  * Inspector Miroslav Bižić accused of hiding evidence and helping Vukotić to flee the country
  * Case never closed
  * Bižić assassinated in 1996, Ašanin murdered in June 1998
  * Club was closed and later reopened, but became a "place to be avoided"

- "Lukas" at Hotel Metropol, 69 Bulevar Kralja Aleksandra:
  * Co-owned by Miroslav Kurak, participant in the assassination of a journalist Slavko Ćuruvija in 1999
  * Known for its mixed clientele: businessmen, members of the diplomatic corps, and gangsters
  * Employees used the last floor in the hotel
  * Police raided the premises in

- "Industrija", located at 19 Vasina Street, was a venue that played only electronic music and was known for its role in the history of the Serbian electronic scene. It was opened in 1994 in the former boiler room of the Philosophy Faculty and hosted DJs such as Deki S.T.R.O.B., Mark Wee, Vlada Eye, Velja Innvision, Gordan Paunović, Vlada Janjić, Boža Podunavac, X-periment, TTP, and Sugardaddy O. Despite international sanctions, foreign DJs such as Moby, Mark EG, and DJ Hell performed there 2-3 times a month.
- "Underground", located in a cave below the Belgrade Fortress, was known for its specific type of music: acid jazz, funk, drum and house. It had a cult status for years but was later closed after the change of proprietors and the beginning of folk music.
- "Apartman", located at 43 Karađorđeva Street, is now closed.
- "Batler" and "Francuska Sobarica" are both located at 12 Francuska Street.
- "Bordel", now "Meduza Club", is located at 6 Gospodar Jevermova Street.
- "Buha", located in the building of the Boško Buha Theatre on the Republic Square, was popular in the 1990-1992 period and was one of the first to play electronic music.
- "Bus" was located in Tašmajdan, close to the Tašmajdan stadium.
- "Dolar", located at the corner of 29 Novembra and Takovska streets, was known for the Pazi Škola evening.
- "Energija", located at 8 Nušičeva Street, was known for the Trashotheque nights.
- "Inkognito", located at 4 Nemanjina Street, was replaced with the "Wash" club in the 2000s.
- "Gajba", located at 71 Kneginje Zorke Street, is now a "Monk's Bar".
- "Ku

- "Magna House" at 9 Dragoslava Jovanovića Street, now a restaurant called "Gradonačelnik", was originally a gathering place for criminals, with notable gangsters such as Aleksandar Knežević Knele and Kristijan Golubović frequenting the establishment.
- "Omen", a techno rave club located at 16 Obilićev Venac Street, was popular among DJs and had an intimate atmosphere with pinball machines at the entrance.
- "Pećina", located at the entry into the Tašmajdan's lagums beneath the park, was the location of the "Ovo je moj grad" festival.
- "Sara", a barge on Ada Ciganlija, was the first venue with solely electronic music, but it was only open for a year in 1994.
- "Soul Food", located at 6 Francuska Street, was labeled as the first club with a strictly defined concept, shaped by dance music. It closed in 1997.
- "F6" and later "Dot" were another disco with a different musical direction.
- "Triton", a splav (floating nightclub), was one of the most popular at the time and was located on water. It was the location of numerous shootouts.
- "Trozubac", located between the city's central square Terazije and Nušićeva Street, was a gathering place of the criminals.
- "Tube", located at the corner of Simina and Dobračina streets, was another gathering place for criminals.
